title: James Hampton (actor)
text:
James Wade Hampton (July 9, 1936 – April 7, 2021) was an American <a href="actor">actor</a>, <a href="television%20director">television director</a>, and <a href="screenwriter">screenwriter</a>. He is best known for his TV roles such as Private Hannibal Shirley Dobbs on "<a href="F%20Troop">F Troop</a>" (1965–1967), and Leroy B. Simpson on "<a href="The%20Doris%20Day%20Show">The Doris Day Show</a>" (1968–1969), "<a href="Love%2C%20American%20Style">Love, American Style</a>" (1969–1974), and his movie roles such as Caretaker in "<a href="The%20Longest%20Yard%20%281974%20film%29">The Longest Yard</a>" (1974), Howard Clemmons in "<a href="Hawmps%21">Hawmps!</a>" (1976), Harold Howard in "<a href="Teen%20Wolf">Teen Wolf</a>" (1985), and Jerry Woolridge in "<a href="Sling%20Blade">Sling Blade</a>" (1996).
Early life.
Hampton was born in <a href="Oklahoma%20City">Oklahoma City</a>, <a href="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>, the son of Edna (Gately), who worked at a millinery, and Ivan Hampton, who ran a dry cleaning business. He was raised in <a href="Dallas%2C%20Texas">Dallas, Texas</a>, and majored in <a href="theatre%20arts">theatre arts</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20North%20Texas">University of North Texas</a> in <a href="Denton%2C%20Texas">Denton</a>. While attending UNT, he was a member of the Gamma Lambda chapter of <a href="Kappa%20Alpha%20Order">Kappa Alpha Order</a>.
After a series of failed jobs including bodyguard, bartender, and photojournalist, he was inducted into the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>. He was stationed in <a href="Germany">Germany</a> and performed with the <a href="USO">USO</a>, for which he won awards.
Career.
Following his service, he performed in <a href="Summer%20stock%20theatre">summer stock</a> in Texas and then moved to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, where he was given his first film role - the <a href="Academy%20Award">Academy Award</a>-nominated short subject "The Cliffdwellers". 
Hampton's next role came as the lead character in a May 1963 "<a href="Gunsmoke">Gunsmoke</a>" episode entitled "Jeb", featuring his friend and series regular <a href="Burt%20Reynolds">Burt Reynolds</a>. He returned to "<a href="Gunsmoke">Gunsmoke</a>" later that year in "Pa Hack’s Brood" (S9E13), again as a character named Jeb, although Marshall Dillon makes no reference in this episode to the previous appearance.
In 1964, Hampton was cast as <a href="Publishing">publisher</a> <a href="William%20Randolph%20Hearst">William Randolph Hearst</a> in the episode "The Paper Dynasty" of the <a href="Television%20syndication">syndicated</a> <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> <a href="television%20series">television series</a>, "<a href="Death%20Valley%20Days">Death Valley Days</a>", hosted by <a href="Stanley%20Andrews">Stanley Andrews</a>. In the story line, Hearst struggles to turn a profit despite increased circulation of "<a href="The%20San%20Francisco%20Examiner">The San Francisco Examiner</a>". James Lanphier (1920-1969) plays <a href="Ambrose%20Bierce">Ambrose Bierce</a>; <a href="Robert%20O.%20Cornthwaite">Robert O. Cornthwaite</a> was cast as Sam Chamberlain.
Hampton is known for his roles in <a href="CBS">CBS</a>'s "<a href="The%20Doris%20Day%20Show">The Doris Day Show</a>" (as Leroy, the handyman); <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>'s "<a href="F%20Troop">F Troop</a>" (as <a href="F%20Troop%23Regular%20characters">Hannibal Dobbs</a> the incompetent bugler); <a href="Robert%20Aldrich">Robert Aldrich</a>'s "<a href="The%20Longest%20Yard%20%281974%20film%29">The Longest Yard</a>" (1974); " (1975)"; "<a href="Teen%20Wolf">Teen Wolf</a>" (1985); <a href="Teen%20Wolf%20%281986%20TV%20series%29">the "Teen Wolf" television series</a> (1986 to 1989); "" (1988); and "<a href="Sling%20Blade%20%28film%29">Sling Blade</a>" (1996). Hampton guest starred as Jim Rockford's cousin Aaron Ironwood in a 1975 episode of <a href="NBC">NBC</a>'s "<a href="The%20Rockford%20Files">The Rockford Files</a>". He received a <a href="TeenNick%20HALO%20Awards">HALO Award</a> for "<a href="Hawmps%21">Hawmps!</a>", and a <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award">Golden Globe Award</a> nomination for "Most Promising Newcomer" for the part of "Caretaker" in "<a href="The%20Longest%20Yard%20%281974%20film%29">The Longest Yard</a>". He was also the spokesman for the <a href="American%20Egg%20Board">American Egg Board</a>.
In 1980, he starred alongside <a href="Gary%20Collins%20%28actor%29">Gary Collins</a> in the low-budget movie "<a href="Hangar%2018%20%28film%29">Hangar 18</a>". It was filmed primarily in <a href="Big%20Spring%2C%20Texas">Big Spring, Texas</a>, and the two played NASA astronauts trying to expose a UFO coverup.
In 2012, Hampton appeared in an advertisement on <a href="MeTV">MeTV</a> touting some of the shows in which he had guest starred, including "<a href="Gomer%20Pyle%2C%20U.S.M.C.">Gomer Pyle, U.S.M.C.</a>" and "<a href="The%20Rockford%20Files">The Rockford Files</a>".
Personal life.
Hampton married his wife, actress Mary Deese, in 2002. He has three children – James, Andrea and Frank. They resided in Texas.
Hampton was married to actress Carole Simpson before they divorced and he remarried in 2002.
Death.
Hampton died of complications from <a href="Parkinson%27s%20disease">Parkinson's disease</a> on April 7, 2021, at his home in <a href="Fort%20Worth%2C%20Texas">Fort Worth, Texas</a>. He was 84.
